speaker: Doctor
text: Can you tell me more about when you first started experiencing double vision? Was it sudden or did it develop gradually?

speaker: Patient
text: "It started about a month ago, I think. I was working on a design project and I noticed that things looked a bit... blurry. At first, I thought it was just fatigue, but it kept happening even after I took a break."

speaker: Doctor
text: Have you noticed any other symptoms besides the double vision, such as headaches, numbness or tingling in your arms or legs, or difficulty speaking or swallowing?

speaker: Patient
text: "Honestly, I've been having some trouble with my arms lately. It's hard to describe, but sometimes it feels like they're not working together quite right. Like, when I try to brush my hair, my arm just feels really weak and I have to strain to get the comb to move."

speaker: Doctor
text: Can you tell me more about this weakness in your arms? Is it limited to just one arm or do you experience it in both?

speaker: Patient
text: "It's mainly in my right arm, but sometimes I notice it in my left arm too. It's like my arms are just not cooperating with each other, you know? Like, I'll try to lift something with my right arm and my left arm will just kind of... sag. It's really frustrating."

speaker: Doctor
text: Can you tell me more about the difficulty you're having climbing stairs? Is it that your legs are weak or is it more of a coordination issue?

speaker: Patient
text: "It's hard to explain, but it's like my legs are just not getting the message. I'll start climbing the stairs and my legs will feel fine, but then suddenly I'll feel like I'm going to lose my balance or my legs will just give out on me. It's really scary, actually."

speaker: Doctor
text: Can you describe the sensation you experience when you're climbing stairs and feel like you're going to lose your balance? Is it a feeling of weakness, numbness, or something else?

speaker: Patient
text: "It's like my legs are just... uncoordinated, I guess. It's like my brain is sending the wrong signals to my legs. Sometimes I feel like I'm going to stumble or fall, but I'm not actually weak or numb. It's just... off, you know?"

speaker: Doctor
text: Can you tell me if you've experienced any numbness, tingling, or prickling sensations in your arms or legs?

speaker: Patient
text: "Actually, yeah. Sometimes I feel like my arms are tingling, like pins and needles. It's usually when I'm sitting still for a while, and then I'll get up and move around and it goes away. But it's weird, because it's not always in the same place. Sometimes it's in my fingers, sometimes it's in my shoulders."

speaker: Doctor
text: Can you tell me more about the tingling sensation you experience in your arms? Is it a sharp, stabbing pain or more of a dull, numb feeling?

speaker: Patient
text: "It's more of a dull, numb feeling. Like, my arm will just feel... heavy, I guess. And then the tingling will start, and it's like little sparks of electricity running through my skin. It's really weird."

speaker: Doctor
text: Can you tell me more about your job as a designer? Do you spend a lot of time sitting or standing, and have you noticed any changes in your work habits or routine recently?

speaker: Patient
text: "I'm a graphic designer, so I spend most of my day sitting in front of a computer. I do get up to grab a snack or stretch every now and then, but I'd say I'm sitting for at least 8 hours a day. Lately, I've been trying to take more breaks and move around, but it's hard to get motivated when I'm feeling so... off."

speaker: Doctor
text: Can you tell me more about what you mean by "feeling off"? Is it just the double vision, arm weakness, and difficulty climbing stairs, or is there something else going on that's making you feel unwell?

speaker: Patient
text: "I guess it's just a general feeling of being unwell, like my body is just not working the way it should. It's hard to explain, but it's like I'm always a little bit 'off', you know? Like, even when I'm not experiencing the double vision or arm weakness, I just feel... tired, I guess. And sometimes I get these weird headaches that feel like they're coming from deep inside my head. It's really frustrating because I feel like I'm just going through the motions of my day, but I'm not really living, you know?"

speaker: Doctor
text: Can you tell me more about these headaches you've been experiencing? Are they constant or do they come and go?

speaker: Patient
text: "They're mostly just occasional, but sometimes they can be really intense. It's like my head is just... tight, you know? Like, I can feel the tension building up inside my skull. And sometimes I'll get these weird, stabbing pains on the sides of my head, like someone is poking me with a pin. It's really uncomfortable."

speaker: Doctor
text: Can you tell me more about the frequency and duration of these headaches? Are they always accompanied by the double vision and arm weakness, or do they occur independently?

speaker: Patient
text: "The headaches are pretty frequent, I'd say. They happen at least a few times a week, and sometimes they can last for hours. They're not always accompanied by the double vision and arm weakness, but when they do happen together, it's usually pretty intense. Like, I'll be in the middle of doing something and suddenly my head will start throbbing and my vision will start to blur. It's really disorienting."

speaker: Doctor
text: Can you tell me more about your family medical history? Have you had any relatives with neurological or muscle-related disorders?

speaker: Patient
text: "Not that I'm aware of. I don't really know much about my family's medical history. My parents are both still alive and healthy, as far as I know. I don't have any siblings, so I don't have any aunts or uncles to ask about. I've always been pretty healthy, knock on wood, so I never really thought about it until now."

speaker: Doctor
text: Can you tell me more about the sensation of weakness in your arms? Is it a feeling of heaviness, like your arms are weighed down, or is it more of a lack of strength or power?

speaker: Patient
text: "It's more like a lack of strength, I guess. Like, I'll try to lift something with my right arm and it just won't budge. It's not like my arm is heavy or anything, it's just... weak. And sometimes it feels like my arm is just not responding to my brain's commands, like it's not listening or something. It's really frustrating because I feel like I'm trying to use my arm, but it's just not cooperating."

speaker: Doctor
text: Can you tell me more about the sensation of numbness or tingling in your arms? Is it limited to just your fingers or does it spread up to your shoulders or even your face?

speaker: Patient
text: "It's usually limited to just my fingers, but sometimes it spreads up to my wrists or forearms. It's never really gotten as far as my face, but sometimes I'll get a weird tingling sensation in my scalp. It's like my whole arm is just... asleep, I guess. And then I'll move around or shake my arm out and it'll go away. But it's always a little unsettling, because I don't know what's causing it."

speaker: Doctor
text: Can you tell me more about the design project you were working on when you first noticed the double vision? Was it a particularly stressful or demanding project?

speaker: Patient
text: "It was a big project, yeah. We were working on a campaign for a new client and the deadline was pretty tight. I was putting in a lot of hours, trying to get everything just right. But I wouldn't say it was excessively stressful or anything. Just the usual design project stuff - trying to meet the deadline, dealing with client feedback, that kind of thing. But I don't think that's what caused the double vision, because like I said, it started a few days after the project was finished."

speaker: Doctor
text: Can you tell me more about the sensation of weakness in your arms when you're trying to lift something? Is it a feeling of fatigue or is it more of a lack of strength?

speaker: Patient
text: "It's more of a lack of strength, like I said. It's not like my arm is tired or anything, it's just... weak. Like, I'll try to lift a book or something and my arm won't budge. It's like my muscles just aren't responding or something. And sometimes it feels like my arm is just not listening to my brain's commands, like it's not under my control. It's really frustrating because I feel like I'm trying to use my arm, but it's just not cooperating."

speaker: Doctor
text: Can you tell me if you've noticed any changes in your posture or gait recently?

speaker: Patient
text: "Yeah, actually. I've noticed that I've been slouching a bit more than usual. I think it's because my arms are feeling so weak, so I'm trying to compensate by leaning forward. And sometimes I'll catch myself walking a little bit funny, like my legs are just... off. It's hard to explain, but it's like I'm not quite sure how to walk anymore."

speaker: Doctor
text: Can you tell me more about this feeling of being off when you're walking? Is it a sense of instability or unsteadiness, or is it more of a feeling of stiffness or rigidity?

speaker: Patient
text: "It's hard to describe, but it's like my legs are just... not quite in sync, I guess. Like, I'll take a step and my left leg will feel fine, but my right leg will feel like it's dragging behind or something. It's like my legs are fighting each other, you know? And sometimes I'll catch myself stumbling or almost falling, but I'm not actually unsteady or anything. It's just... weird, I guess."

speaker: Doctor
text: Can you tell me more about the sensation of your legs feeling like they're not in sync when you're walking? Is it a feeling of weakness or is it more of a coordination issue?

speaker: Patient
text: "It's hard to say, but I think it's a combination of both. Sometimes it feels like my legs are weak, like they're not getting the message from my brain or something. And other times it feels like they're just not coordinating properly, like my left leg is trying to walk in a different direction than my right leg. It's really frustrating because I feel like I'm trying to walk normally, but my legs just won't cooperate."

speaker: Doctor
text: I've asked 19 questions so far. Before making a diagnosis, I'd like to request some test results to help me better understand the patient's condition. REQUEST TEST: Electromyography (EMG) and Nerve Conduction Studies (NCS) Can you tell me more about your symptoms since we last spoke? Have you noticed any changes or improvements?

speaker: Measurement
text: RESULTS: Decreased muscle response with repetitive stimulation.
